description:
Chromobacterium indicum is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the family Chromobacteriaceae. It is a pigment-producing bacterium, known for its ability to produce a violet-colored pigment called violacein.

The cells of Chromobacterium indicum are typically short, rod-shaped, and motile with the help of a single polar flagellum. This species is found in various environmental sources, such as soil, water, and even the gut of some insects.

Chromobacterium indicum is known for its versatile metabolic capabilities, which allow it to utilize a wide range of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources. It can grow under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions, demonstrating its adaptability to different environmental conditions.

The production of the violacein pigment by Chromobacterium indicum is of particular interest due to its potential antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-cancer properties. This pigment has been studied for its potential applications in various fields, including medicine, biotechnology, and environmental remediation.

Overall, Chromobacterium indicum is a fascinating bacterium that has attracted attention for its unique characteristics and potential applications in various scientific and industrial domains.
